title: Getting Started with TypeScript
description: A complete beginner's guide to understanding and setting up TypeScript

sections.title: What is TypeScript?
sections.content: TypeScript is a programming language developed by Microsoft that builds on JavaScript by adding static types. Think of it as JavaScript with superpowers! While JavaScript lets you write code without declaring what type of data you're working with, TypeScript requires you to be explicit about your data types. This helps catch errors before your code even runs.
keyPoints: TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript - all JavaScript code is valid TypeScript
It adds optional static typing to catch errors during development
TypeScript code compiles down to plain JavaScript
Major companies like Microsoft, Google, and Airbnb use TypeScript

sections.title: Why Learn TypeScript?
sections.content: Imagine you're building a house. JavaScript is like building without blueprints - you can do it, but mistakes are easy to make. TypeScript gives you those blueprints. It helps you catch mistakes early, makes your code easier to understand, and provides better tooling support with autocomplete and documentation.
benefits: Catch bugs before runtime - your editor will show you errors as you type
Better autocomplete - your editor knows what properties and methods are available
Easier refactoring - when you change code, TypeScript helps find all affected areas
Self-documenting code - types serve as inline documentation
Scales better for large projects - easier to maintain as your codebase grows

sections.title: Setting Up Your First TypeScript Project
sections.content: Let's walk through setting up TypeScript step by step. Don't worry if this seems like a lot - you only need to do this once per project!

steps.description: First, you need Node.js installed on your computer. Download it from nodejs.org. This gives you npm (Node Package Manager), which we'll use to install TypeScript.
steps.explanation: Run this to verify Node.js is installed. You should see a version number like v18.0.0

steps.description: Open your terminal or command prompt and run this command. The -g flag installs TypeScript globally so you can use it anywhere on your computer.
steps.explanation: This downloads and installs the TypeScript compiler on your system

steps.description: Create a new folder for your project and navigate into it.
steps.command:
mkdir my-typescript-project
cd my-typescript-project
npm init -y
steps.explanation: This creates a folder and initializes a Node.js project with a package.json file

steps.description: Create a tsconfig.json file that tells TypeScript how to compile your code.
steps.explanation: This creates a tsconfig.json file with sensible defaults and lots of comments explaining each option

steps.description: Create a file named index.ts (note the .ts extension for TypeScript files)
steps.explanation: This simple function takes a string parameter and returns a string. TypeScript will ensure you always pass a string to this function.

steps.description: Use the TypeScript compiler to convert your .ts file to JavaScript, then run it with Node.
steps.explanation: The tsc command compiles index.ts to index.js. Then Node.js runs the JavaScript file.

sections.title: Understanding the Compilation Process
sections.content: TypeScript doesn't run directly in browsers or Node.js. It needs to be compiled (converted) to JavaScript first. Think of TypeScript as a translator that converts your type-safe code into regular JavaScript that can run anywhere.
process: TypeScript compiler checks for type errors
If no errors, it generates JavaScript files (.js files)
The JavaScript files run in browsers or Node.js
During compilation, all type information is removed - it only exists to help you during development

sections.title: Your Development Workflow
sections.content: Here's how you'll typically work with TypeScript day-to-day:

workflow.description: Write your TypeScript code in .ts files. Your code editor (like VS Code) will show type errors in real-time as you type.
TypeScript continuously checks your code for type errors. Red squiggly lines indicate problems.
Run 'tsc' to compile your TypeScript to JavaScript. Fix any errors the compiler finds.
Run your compiled JavaScript code in Node.js or a browser.
Use source maps to debug your original TypeScript code even though JavaScript is running.

sections.title: Common Beginner Mistakes to Avoid
sections.content: Here are mistakes that trip up newcomers:

mistakes.mistake: Not understanding the difference between .ts and .js files
mistakes.solution: Remember: .ts files are your source code with types. .js files are the compiled output that actually runs. Never edit the .js files - always edit .ts files.
You must compile TypeScript to JavaScript first. Use 'tsc filename.ts' then 'node filename.js'
The 'any' type defeats the purpose of TypeScript. Use specific types to get the benefits of type checking.
TypeScript error messages are actually very helpful! They tell you exactly what's wrong and where.

sections.title: Next Steps
sections.content: Now that you have TypeScript set up, you're ready to learn about types! The next lesson will cover basic types - the building blocks of TypeScript. Take your time with each lesson and practice writing code. The more you use TypeScript, the more natural it will feel.
